Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Academy in Sustainable BioEnergy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a renewal of an REU site around the theme of sustainable bioenergy that trains future scientists and engineers with the skills and perspective necessary to address the world's future energy needs. To accomplish this, students perform research in sustainable energy, attend seminars on topics related to sustainability and personal development, and work on a team project related to sustainable energy. Students are required to present their research in a symposium at the end of the program as well as report their findings on a website. Nine students are recruited each year for a 10-week summer program. Targeted recruitment is done to enhance the diversity of the REU participants. The program impacts the REU participants by providing them training in the skills and knowledge they need for research in sustainable energy, giving them a sense of the broader picture of sustainability, and helping them develop the personal skills they will need to be successful engineers and scientists. Sixty percent of the past participants who have graduated with a BS degree are now in graduate studies. One hundred percent of the participants indicated that the REU program positively impacted their career.

Intellectual Merit:

The research produced by the REU students under the guidance of their faculty mentors advance the state of knowledge in sustainable energy. Researchers will make advancements in the areas of conversion of biomass to fuels and chemicals, development of sustainable agricultural practices, and advance the understanding of how rural communities are impacted by these systems.

Broader Impacts:

This REU site provides a rich research experience focused on the personal and professional development of the participants. Students will gain not only the technical abilities required to conduct research in sustainable energy, but also become aware of the social and political issues associated with sustainable energy. By being involved in a team project on sustainable energy, students learn to seek outside sources of information and gain an increased capacity for self-directed learning and original investigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to create an REU site centered on the theme of sustainable energy to train future engineers, agricultural scientists and social scientists with the silks and perspective necessary to address the world’s future sustainable energy needs, particularly focusing on biomass and biofuels.  The project trained 10 REU students each year (2014, 2015 and 2017) of the project. Each student had to complete an interdisciplinary team project involving sustainable energy; attend weekly educational research seminars on sustainable energy processes, impacts on rural communities and the environment, energy industries and agribusiness, and co-product development; attend personal development and graduate school informational seminars; attend a weekly data analytics course; receive lab safety training; partake in brownbag lunches and social events; participate in experiential learning trips with industry and collaborators; professionally present their research at a research symposium; and produce a professional research report. Students received interdisciplinary and individualized training in the fields of engineering, agricultural sciences, economics and sociology that will allow them to undertake future research and career paths in fields related to sustainable and renewable energy.

            The project helped to advance the state of knowledge in fields of study related to sustainable energy in an interdisciplinary environment. Advances were achieved in the engineering sciences, including: biofuel production processes; handling and treatment of biomass feedstocks for biofuel production; development of membranes for reactors used to produce biofuels; production of co-products from biofuel production; production of bio-based chemicals; thermal and biochemical processing of biomass; solar energy production and associated co-products; and examination of catalysts needed for sustainable energy production. Advances were achieved in the agricultural sciences, including: biomass feedstock yield and production; impacts on soil sustainability from harvesting of crop biomass for biofuel production; biomass handling and storage; environmental impacts and greenhouse gas emissions from biomass production; and relationships between biofuel and livestock production. Advances were achieved in the economic and social sciences, including:  energy demand and supply; economics of biofuel production at the farm scale; farmers’ willingness to produce alternative biofuel feedstocks; impact of biofuel production on local rural communities; agricultural land-use change from biofuel production; contractual relationships between producers and energy-based agribusiness firms; and perceived impacts of biofuel production on the local environment.  Unique is that all the research was completed using an integrated approach uniting social, economics, engineering and agricultural sciences to provide answers to research questions that will help to shape sustainable energy pathway in the future. All participants completed a professional project report, professionally presented their research to mentors, colleagues and the general public, and created personal web pages documenting their experiences. Research from the REU has been published in Ceramic International, Journal of Extension and Rural Studies, Journal of Membrane Science, Land-Use Science and Transactions of the ASABE. REU participants have presented their research at national and international conferences.

            The REU program provided 30 undergraduate students a rich research experience focused on both personal and professional development of the participants. Participants came from undergraduate backgrounds in sociology and economics (43%); engineering (33 %); and agricultural sciences (24%). Participants gained knowledge in the engineering, agricultural, social and economic issues related to sustainable energy production, as well as focused technical skills and training in these areas. By being involved in interdisciplinary team environment, participants learned to consider multiple facets of research problems; assess real world implications; gained an increased capacity for self-directed learning and original investigation; and learned how to conduct, present and report on professional research to colleagues and the public. The program had 30 students in total, of which 57% were female, 40% were nonwhite, 3% were disabled and 20% were from institutions serving underrepresented groups. We achieved a strong mix of diversity, as well as the ability to enhance the participation of students from underrepresented groups in research and in graduate school. When students exited the program, within 1-2 years, over 70% of the REU participants in the program indicated that they would pursue advanced (MS and PhD) degrees and careers in research, with up to 60% of a cohort actually entering graduate at some point after the program. Students pursued careers in sustainable energy, as well as Fulbright Scholarship and other international opportunities, as well.  

            Past participants were unanimous about their enthusiasm for their REU experience and felt that it broadened their perspective on life as a research scientist and positively impacted their ability to succeed in graduate studies. Post-participation surveys indicated that students participating in this REU: (1) had strong support from their mentor; (2) had an excellent working relationship with their mentor; (3) established professional contacts with researchers in the field; (4) received excellent advice about careers and graduate school; (5) contributed to the field of bioenergy research; and (6) understood what everyday research work is like.
